title: 104_s1312
content: The Act titled "Middle Class Education Opportunity Act of 1995" includes an amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Section 101 introduces a deduction for higher education expenses under a new section 220 for tuition and fees. The deduction for qualified higher education expenses paid by an individual is limited to $5,000 per taxable year based on modified adjusted gross income. The modified adjusted gross income of the taxpayer for the taxable year is determined without regard to specific sections and after the application of other sections. Adjusted gross income for purposes of certain deductions is calculated without considering the deduction allowed under this section. Qualified higher education expenses are limited to $5,000 per taxable year based on modified adjusted gross income. The term 'qualified higher education expenses' refers to tuition and fees required for enrollment of the taxpayer, spouse, or dependent as an eligible student at a higher education institution. It excludes expenses related to sports, games, or hobbies. The term 'qualified higher education expenses' excludes expenses for sports, games, or hobbies unless part of a degree program or deductible under the tax code. It also does not include nonacademic fees like student activity fees or insurance expenses. An eligible student must meet certain requirements under the Higher Education Act of 1965. The enactment of this section requires eligible students to carry a half-time workload or be enrolled in a course to improve job skills. Taxpayers must provide identification information for eligible students on their tax return. The term 'institution of higher education' is defined as an institution eligible for programs under title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965. No double benefit is allowed for qualified higher education expenses if a deduction is available under another tax provision, unless the taxpayer waives the right to the deduction. The deduction for qualified higher education expenses is limited if another taxpayer can claim a deduction for the same individual. Additionally, the deduction is only allowed for expenses that exceed the amount excludable under section 135 for the taxable year. The deduction for qualified higher education expenses is limited to expenses in connection with enrollment at an institution of higher education during the taxable year. Prepayments are allowed for expenses related to an academic term beginning in the taxable year or the first 3 months of the next year. The amount of expenses is reduced by certain scholarships and veterans benefits before applying other deductions. The deduction for qualified higher education expenses is limited to expenses related to enrollment at an institution of higher education during the taxable year. The deduction is reduced by scholarships, veterans benefits, and other payments exempt from income taxation. Married individuals filing separate returns are not eligible for this deduction. The deduction for qualified higher education expenses is limited to enrollment at an institution of higher education during the taxable year. If the taxpayer is a married individual, this section applies only if they file a joint return with their spouse. For nonresident alien individuals, this section applies if they are treated as a resident alien of the United States. The Secretary may prescribe regulations to carry out this section. Additionally, a deduction is allowed in computing adjusted gross income. The deduction for higher education tuition and fees under section 220 is added as paragraph (16) to section 62(a). A conforming amendment is made to the table of sections by striking the item relating to section 220. The deduction for higher education tuition and fees under section 220 is added as paragraph (16) to section 62(a) and applies to payments made after December 31, 1995.
